message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including abdominal pain, vomiting, constipation, and a sausage-shaped abdominal mass suggest intussusception, and the blue-gray macules on the buccal mucosa suggest Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is caused by a mutation in the STK11 gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest intussusception, which is associated with a mutation in the STK11 gene. The other options are associated with other genetic conditions such as gastrointestinal stromal tumors (C-KIT) and neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest intussusception, which occurs when part of the intestine slides into an adjacent part of the intestine. The presence of mucocutaneous blue-gray macules on the child’s buccal mucosa indicates a genetic predisposition to this condition, specifically a mutation in the STK11 gene, which is associated with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a sausage-shaped abdominal mass, tenderness to palpation, and mucocutaneous blue-gray macules on buccal mucosa suggest intussusception. Intussusception is associated with a mutation in STK11 gene. None of the other options are associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including abdominal pain and a sausage-shaped abdominal mass, suggest intussusception, which is associated with a mutation in STK11 gene. The mucocutaneous blue-gray macules indicate Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which is also associated with a mutation in STK11 gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation of abdominal pain, vomiting, and a sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant suggests intussusception, a telescoping of one part of the intestine into another. Mucocutaneous blue-gray macules in the buccal mucosa is a characteristic finding in patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome, which is associated with a mutation in the STK11 gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest intussusception, which is associated with a mutation in the STK11 gene. The other options are associated with other conditions. C-KIT mutations are associated with gastrointestinal stromal tumors, NF1 mutations are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1, and APC mutations are associated with familial adenomatous polyposis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant suggest intussusception. The mucocutaneous blue-gray macules on the child’s buccal mucosa are called “Hutchinson’s sign” and are indicative of neurofibromatosis, which is associated with a mutation in the NF1 gene. Therefore, the correct answer is (B).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation, including severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and a sausage-shaped abdominal mass, along with mucocutaneous blue-gray macules on the child's buccal mucosa, are characteristic of intussusception. Intussusception has been associated with a mutation in the STK11 gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest that the patient is suffering from intussusception. Mucocutaneous blue-gray macules in the buccal mucosa are indicative of Peutz–Jeghers syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in the STK11 gene.
